Drifting is characterized by a greater rear slip angle than front slip angle, often resulting in the front wheels pointing in the opposite direction of the turn (e.g. turning left, wheels pointed right or vice versa). D1NZ is a production car drifting series in New Zealand that began in 2003 as a small competition and has since grown into a professional series with professional drivers and sponsored cars. The series includes two championships: Pro and Pro-sport, and new competitors typically need to prove themselves in the Pro-sport championship before entering the Pro championship. The series aims to promote and educate drifting in a regulated and safe environment, and is recognized as the longest running drifting series in the world.

The draft, also known as conscription, has been employed by the federal government in four conflicts: the American Civil War, World War I, World War II, and the Cold War (including both the Korean and Vietnam Wars). From 1940 to 1973, men were drafted to fill vacancies in the US Armed Forces that could not be filled through voluntary means. The draft was ended when the US Armed Forces transitioned to an all-volunteer military force, but the Selective Service System remains in place as a contingency plan. All male civilians between the ages of 18 and 25 are required to register so that a draft can be readily resumed if needed.

The lamp used in many lighthouses is similar to the Argand lamp, which was patented in 1780 by Aimé Argand. The Argand lamp was brighter than earlier lamps, with an output of 6 to 10 candela, and required less frequent wick trimming due to its more complete combustion of the candle wick and oil. The Lewis lamp, invented by Winslow Lewis and patented in 1810, used a similar design to the Argand lamp but with a parabolic reflector and a magnifying lens made of green bottle glass. While the Argand variant was widely used by European lighthouses, the Lewis lamp design was chosen by the United States for use in American lighthouses.

Passage: Leinster ( — — ) is one of the Provinces of Ireland situated in the east of Ireland. It comprises the ancient Kingdoms of Mide, Osraige, and Leinster. Following the 12th-century Norman invasion of Ireland, the historic fifths of Leinster and Mide gradually merged, mainly due to the impact of the Pale, which straddled both, thereby forming the present-day province of Leinster. The ancient kingdoms were shired into a number of counties for administrative and judicial purposes. In later centuries, local government legislation has seen further sub-division of the historic counties.

Answer: Leinster.

Patrick Kennedy, a folklorist from Co. Wexford, Ireland, is known for his collections of Irish folktales from Leinster. The tales are told in the rusticated English of the Irish peasantry who had established roots in The Pale, the anglicized part of Ireland. Kennedy is widely credited with preserving Irish idioms in the turn of phrase, sentence structure, and Irish words.
